ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I am now much more efficient in my abilities to speak and especially write in Spanish! I never imagined that I would be able to express such complicated topics as globalization and xenophobia, especially as it relates to Latin American countries, in a different language! I'm so grateful to Yale and Profesora Sab for the opportunity to expand myself intellectually and personally as I try to meet and exceed my goal of Spanish fluency.

Strengthened use of various verb tenses; Speak with greater clarity, fluidity, and detail about various worldly topics; Analysis of cultural works including short stories, books, and songs; Improve ability to hold impromptu conversations
Large improvements to complicated spanish grammar and some vocab.

I enriched my understanding of and competency in the Spanish language. This included learning more advanced grammar and syntactical devices. Also, we learned a lot about the history and culture of many different Spanish-speaking countries.

I further developed my knowledge of the Spanish language by expanding my vocabulary in different subjects (health, history, art, emotions, relationships), as well as my understanding of Spanish grammar, like the future tense, the conditional, andsi clauses.
Oral skills, analysis, grammar, reading

This class helped push me out of my comfort zone to be able to have discussions in Spanish without being embarrassed about making mistakes. The class was less lecture-based than my previous Spanish classes, and I learned more about how to have insightful conversations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was the best language course I have take so far. Profesora Sab is remarkable. I hope you can give her an award for going to extraordinary lengths to make her students feel comfortable with speaking in Spanish during class and for having the most reassuring personality. She posed very thought-provoking questions. In this class, I have seen my intellect grow significantly through Profa Sab's instruction and personality.
Professor Lourdes Sab was great and the content was interesting especially towards the end of the semester. I wish the course had less graded homework and assessments.

Strength: Professor Sabe is a very engaged professor who is committed to ensuring her students are prepared not just for class material but also for adopting the Spanish language and culture; Detailed feedback
Weakness: Although the class is 1.5 credits, there is still a lot of work and not a lot of time to complete it; Little opportunity to catch up if you fall behind
A strength of the course is the frequency of work in order to keep using spanish, however a weakness was lots of busy work which was also graded harshly, making it not enjoyable while completing.

This class was really well designed! The daily workload was fairly consistent and we followed the syllabus nearly perfectly. The cultural and historical elements were especially enjoyable and important during this phase of language learning.

Strengths: The high level of engagement and constant, consistent practice pushed me to improve my Spanish speaking skills. Even though this class was a lot of work, it definitely forces you to grow as a language learner overall.  

Weaknesses: Sometimes big assignments like essays, special projects, and exams were back to back in the syllabus. Standing alone, each project is very helpful and conducive to learning, but when all these big  assignments are so back to  back, it  actually winds up hindering students learning and progress. I would recommend a revision of the syllabus layout so as to  avoid these back to back occurrences.
I was able to apply material learned well and understood conceptual focuses. I could have been more engaged and worked more on my oral skills
The class is really helpful for students who want to grow in their speaking abilities.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The breakout rooms were very helpful! I was still able to engage with my classmates despite being in an online format. It was these connections that I made that both expanded my ability to conversationally speak in Spanish and to feel at home in the Yale community this semester.

Success: A lot of interaction between students and many opportunities to share ideas/present to the class
Improve: The professor was very adamant of keeping cameras AND microphones on which made it difficult for all parties to actively participate in class
the in person class was successful, but the asynchronous days where there was still just as much or often times more work due the next day was difficult to manage.

Overall, the COVID-adapted practices functioned very well. The use of Canvas Modules to organize each week was extremely helpful for staying on top of assignments and for reviewing previous materials for tests.
Enforcing the microphone-on rule definitely helped with the online Zoom format,  as it reduced student anxiety over participating and being involved in the class.
I think the class format was good (large and small group discussion, group projects, class activities)

Despite the technological barrier, we were still able to have good discussions about important topics. The downfall, though, was that it was really difficult to establish relationships with peers, and made the class seem more independent than my previous in-person classes have been.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This is a terrific class with a reassuring professor! I received such clear feedback that greatly sped up my learning process in Spanish.
Language requirement
If it is a requirement, yes, but I would be prepared to spend at least 10-15 hours/week if you would like to do well
Yes! An amazing course that touches on cultural and historical elements important for contextualizing our language learning. Fantastic prof as well.

If  you are willing to put the work in and dedicate yourself to this course, definitely take it!! it is a great class to improve your Spanish with,  as it is very structured and full of genuinely helpful, directed practice. Just be willing to dedicate  a significant amount  of time to coursework.
If they need to fulfill a language required yes, but if not know because it has a very heavy workload.
I would definitely recommend this class even to students who have their foreign language requirement. I learned a lot and saw my Spanish-speaking abilities grow tremendously.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Profesora also had office hours every Monday and Wednesday. I really appreciated the extra time she invested to make sure her students felt supported! She is such a remarkable teacher that I can't speak highly enough of!
none
Three synchronous days, which consisted of a virtual seminar. Two asynchronous days with Canvas or workbook-based lessons and work.
Live virtual lecture, virtual seminar, discussion format
There were also asynchronous assignments/lessons.
